y = .................................................... $cm$ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[916, 440, 920, 458]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 471, 144, 489]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 471, 703, 489]]<|/det|> The student places a load P of weight \(P = 2.0 \text{N}\) on the metre ruler. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 502, 920, 534]]<|/det|> He adjusts the position of the load so that the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced. He measures the distance \(x\) from the centre of P to the zero end of the ruler. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 920, 581]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure using loads of weight \(P = 3.0 \text{N}\), \(4.0 \text{N}\), \(5.0 \text{N}\) and \(6.0 \text{N}\). The values of \(P\) and \(x\) are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 594, 541, 612]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 625, 636, 778]]<|/det|>
\(P/\mathrm {N}\)\(x/\mathrm {cm}\)

3.023.1
4.030.0
5.033.8
6.036.8

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
The student looks from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1, to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{AB}\) of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 860, 121]]<|/det|>
He adjusts his line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 131, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
He places two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\), between his eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\), \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 176, 566, 195]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the change in resistance of a lamp filament when the current in the lamp is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 420, 136]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 285, 166]]<|/det|>
· a power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 384, 183]]<|/det|>
· a low-voltage filament lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 255, 198]]<|/det|>
· an ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 198, 255, 212]]<|/det|>
· a voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 213, 301, 228]]<|/det|>
· connecting wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 702, 260]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate the change in resistance of the lamp filament when the current in the lamp is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 312, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\), where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp and \(I\) is the current in the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 217, 386]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 401, 440, 417]]<|/det|>
· draw a diagram of the circuit used

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 416, 801, 433]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the investigation, including how to change the current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 432, 920, 464]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 463, 616, 480]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 73, 561, 88]]<|/det|>
